results.title: The Shadow Over East Timor
results.creator_credit: Denis Freney, James Kesteven and Mandy King
results.brief_description: In December 1975, 20,000 Indonesian troops invaded East Timor. Australia turned a blind eye and the United States increased its military aid to Indonesia. This conflict is the least reported in modern history and this film brings to light eyewitness accounts of the real events - the massacres, famines, corruption and the resistance that still continues.

results.title: The Shadow of progress
results.creator_credit: Humphrey Swingler, Greenpark Productions, British Petroleum and Derek Williams
results.brief_description: Surveys the problems of exhaustion and destruction of natural resources, pollution and ecological disturbance due to industry, discussing examples of damage to the environment and of constructive counter-measures undertaken around the world.

results.title: The Shadow of ignorance: An inquiry
results.brief_description: Venereal disease in Britain, a programme introduced by Jo Grimmond, M.P. It avoids moral issues, and concentrates on facts: the symptoms of infection, the confidential nature of treatment at a special clinic and the contact slips for patients to give to those who infected them. At the end, three patients are interviewed: a prostitute, a boy and a girl (who talks good sense about parental attitudes). To some extent it will discourage promiscuity; certainly by making it clear that treatment is neither embarrassing nor painful it will encourage those who suspect that they have been infected to seek treatment. Restriction: To be shows to members and students of the medical profession and nursing profession.

results.title: The Sexton
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, ONF | NFB, Raymond Garceau and Dennis Gillson
results.brief_description: An intimate study of a figure whose faithful service behind the scenes contributes to the peace and orderliness of the church. In a little French-Canadian village we meet Monsieur Eusebe, whose whole life has been the care of his parish church and whose proprietary attitude and dour exterior serve only to conceal the love and satisfaction he finds in his work. We see how a sexton’s work is never done as a funeral follows a wedding followed by a christening. And always there is the preparation and tidying up for the next occasion.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernard Devlin, ONF | NFB, Raymond Garceau and Dennis Gillson

results.title: The Sexes: what's the difference?
results.creator_credit: Roman Bittman, Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Examines the question of whether or not there are certain basic biological differences between males and females. The assertion that the socialisation of children totally determines their social behaviour and attitudes is disputed. Environmental factors may not be the sole determinants of sex roles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: The Sewing room
results.creator_credit: Judy Schreiber, Australian Film Commission and Rick Randall
results.brief_description: Australian short film set in the 1950s revolves around the shifting dynamics of a working class family. Pip is a young boy of about ten who puzzles over the goings on within his home, especially the relationship between his brawling parents. Revelling in the presence of his loving, nurturing mother, a dressmaker and homemaker, Pip regards in awe and fear, his cantankerous father, Jack. Jack grapples with his role within the small family, lashing out at his wife and son due to their strained financial situation. “The Sewing room” is a melancholic, nostalgic work that evokes fractured memories of an unpredictable childhood. Cast consists of Maude Davey, Nicolas Anderson and Robert Menzies.

results.title: The Seventh veil
results.creator_credit: Sydney Box, Ortus Films, Theatrecraft and Compton Bennett
results.brief_description: After a car accident Francesca Cunningham (Ann Todd), a gifted pianist, falls into a comatose state, which baffles her doctors. An intuitive psychiatrist puts her under hypnosis in order to unravel the origins of her mental torment and heal her trauma. Under hypnosis (and henceforth told in flashback), Cunningham regales the doctor with tales of her tumultuous past: caning at school, death of her parents, and being made the ward of her very wealthy but emotionally crippled second cousin Nicholas (James Mason). Nicholas recognised in her a unique talent for the piano and committed Francesca to years of relentless study in order for her to become a professional classical musician. Even as an adult Nicholas still wields enormous emotional power over Francesca, preventing her from realising true personal happiness. “The Seventh veil” is an intense psychodrama, which uses gothic sets and expressionistic lighting to convey a grave sense of mental torture for its principal characters. Winner of an Academy award for best original screenplay in 1947, this film was a box-office success in Britain.

results.title: The Seventh seal
results.creator_credit: Allan Ekelund, Svensk Filmindustri and Ingmar Bergman
results.brief_description: Ingmar Bergman’s “Seventh seal” deserves its reputation as a benchmark in the lexicon of modern cinema. With striking imagery, captivating characters and deep philosophical arguments Bergman weaves a rich tapestry as only a master can. Set in the middle ages in the midst of the plague, Antonius Block (Max Von Sydow) is a knight returning from the crusades. When Death (Bengt Ekerot) appears before him he suggests a game of chess to forestall his fate. He travels to his home with an assortment of characters, including his atheist squire Jons (Gunnar Bjornstrand) and a troupe of travelling players. Despite it’s metaphysical content “The Seventh Seal” also includes a heavy dose of Scandinavian humour. In Swedish with english subtitles.
